senses.de: A group of people who gather to listen, watch, or take part in something
senses.ex: The concert had an audience of thousands.

Tips.title: Active Involvement
Tips.description: The audience can be participative, responding to the performance or speaker.
Tips.example: The comedian enjoyed the audience's laughter and engagement.

Tips.title: Live Presence
Tips.description: This audience physically attends the event, like a concert or play.
Tips.example: The theatre was filled with an excited audience.

senses.de: People who watch or listen to a particular television or radio program, movie, or play
senses.ex: The show has a large audience.

Tips.title: Supportive Fans
Tips.description: Media audience implies a fan base that consistently follows a show or series.
Tips.example: The audience eagerly awaited the season finale.

Tips.title: Target Demographic
Tips.description: Shows are often tailored for a specific audience, like children or adults.
Tips.example: The new cartoon series has found its audience among kids.

senses.de: The readership for printed matter, like a book or magazine
senses.ex: The book is meant for a young audience.

Tips.title: Specific Interests
Tips.description: Books and magazines target an audience with particular interests or needs.
Tips.example: The magazine's audience is those interested in technology.

Tips.title: Engagement Levels
Tips.description: A readership audience may interact with content by sharing or discussing it.
Tips.example: The author's blog has built a loyal audience that shares her posts.

senses.de: An official meeting with an important person
senses.ex: The ambassador received an audience with the queen.

Tips.title: Formality
Tips.description: An audience with a dignitary is a formal event with accepted protocols.
Tips.example: He dressed formally for his audience with the official.

Tips.title: Exclusive Meeting
Tips.description: Such an audience is usually exclusive and requires a prior arrangement.
Tips.example: After months of waiting, she finally had an audience with the minister.

Constituent.wordDefinition:
A constituent refers to a member of a group or organization who has the power to elect representatives. It is applicable in political contexts where people vote for their representatives in government.

For example, a constituent could be a person who lives in a certain area and has the power to vote for their representative in Congress.

An audience is a group of people present to watch or listen to something, whereas a constituent is a member of a group with the power to choose representatives.

Crowd.wordDefinition:
Crowd refers to a large, often unorganized group of people who gather together for various reasons, such as a protest, celebration, or emergency.

Crowds can be lively and noisy, with individuals coming and going throughout the event.

In summary, audiences are typically more structured and focused on a specific event, while crowds are larger and less structured gatherings of people.

Guest.wordDefinition:
Guest refers to a person who has been invited to an event, gathering or place. For example, if you are invited to a party at your friend's house, you are their guest.

So, in simple terms, an audience is a group of people who observe a performance or presentation, while a guest is someone who has been invited or welcomed to an event or place.

Onlooker.wordDefinition:
Both audience and onlooker refer to people who are watching or observing something.

Onlooker usually describes an individual who is simply observing an event as it unfolds, without necessarily being part of a larger group.

For example, someone who watches a parade from the sidelines could be considered an onlooker.

Patron.wordDefinition:
Patron typically refers to a person who supports or sponsors an artist, organization, or event financially.

A patron might donate money to a theater or symphony orchestra, for example, in order to help keep it running.

Audience refers to the people who are experiencing an event, while patron refers to a person who supports that event behind the scenes.

Spectator.wordDefinition:
A spectator is someone who is present at an event but not actively participating in it. This term is commonly used in sports events or outdoor activities, where spectators watch the game or activity from the sidelines or stands.

Audience is applicable in the context of live entertainment while spectator is used in the context of watching a sports event or outdoor activity.

Viewer.wordDefinition:
The viewer refers to someone who is watching a recorded or broadcasted program, such as a movie or TV show. It suggests a sense of passivity or observation without direct interaction.

Audience applies to live events and involves participation, while viewer applies to recorded or broadcasted media and suggests passive observation.

Witness.wordDefinition:
Witness refers to a person who sees or experiences something and can testify about it. This is often used in a legal context.

For example, if someone witnesses a crime, they may have to go to court and testify about what they saw.

The main difference between these words is that audience refers to a group of people who are observing something for entertainment or information, while witness refers to an individual who saw something happen and can give testimony about it.

quotes.Text: What I've discovered is that in art, as in music, there's a lot of truth-and then there's a lie. The artist is essentially creating his work to make this lie a truth, but he slides it in amongst all the others. The tiny little lie is the moment I live for, my moment. It's the moment that the audience falls in love.
quotes.Title: American Singer
quotes.Name: Lady Gaga

quotes.Text: You're creating a different world and the actor's job is to be able to convince the audience to enter into that world, whether it be actually something that you recognize from your own life or not.
quotes.Title: Welsh Actor
quotes.Name: Christian Bale

quotes.Text: I don't know whether it's audiences or filmmakers who want characters to be likable today, but I don't think actors are afraid of their characters being unlikable.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Dakota Fanning

quotes.Text: I can think of nothing that an audience won't understand. The only problem is to interest them; once they are interested, they understand anything in the world.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Orson Welles

quotes.Text: I like to change characters and then, slowly I believe the audience treat me as, like an actor who can fight. It's not like an action star.
quotes.Title: Chinese Actor
quotes.Name: Jackie Chan

quotes.Text: When a family film is done well, there's a character that every member of the audience can relate to. I want to be one of those guys.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Dwayne Johnson

quotes.Text: Tell the audience what you're going to say, say it; then tell them what you've said.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Dale Carnegie

quotes.Text: On the stage, you have to find truth, even if you have to lose the audience.
quotes.Title: Mexican Actor
quotes.Name: Anthony Quinn

quotes.Text: The most important thing is that you don't bore the audience.
quotes.Title: Actress
quotes.Name: Jacqueline Fernandez

quotes.Text: I want my audiences to be as open-minded as my characters.
quotes.Title: Canadian Director
quotes.Name: Jason Reitman
